title: Overall
stimulusHtml:
Intent of Question

The primary goals of this question were to assess a student’s ability to (1) calculate a probability from a normal distribution and (2) apply properties of means and variances of functions of random variables.

Solution

Part (a):

Let W denote the weight of a randomly selected full carton of eggs. W has a normal distribution with mean 840 grams and standard deviation 7.9 grams.

The z-score for a weight of 850 grams is z = 850 − 840 7.9 ≈ 1.27. MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiVu0Je9sqqrpepC0xbbL8F4rqqrFfpeea0xe9Lq=Jc9 vqaqpepm0xbba9pwe9Q8fs0=yqaqpepae9pg0FirpepeKkFr0xfr=x fr=xb9adbaqaaeGaciGaaiaabeqaamaabaabaaGcbaGaamOEaiabg2 da9maalaaabaGaaGioaiaaiwdacaaIWaGaeyOeI0IaaGioaiaaisda caaIWaaabaGaaG4naiaac6cacaaI5aaaaiabgIKi7kaaigdacaGGUa GaaGOmaiaaiEdacaGGUaaaaa@44F0@

The standard normal probability table reveals that

P ( W > 850 ) = P ( Z > 1.27 ) ≈ 1 − 0.8980 = 0.1020. MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiVu0Je9sqqrpepC0xbbL8F4rqqrFfpeea0xe9Lq=Jc9 vqaqpepm0xbba9pwe9Q8fs0=yqaqpepae9pg0FirpepeKkFr0xfr=x fr=xb9adbaqaaeGaciGaaiaabeqaamaabaabaaGcbaGaamiuamaabm aabaGaam4vaiabg6da+iaaiIdacaaI1aGaaGimaaGaayjkaiaawMca aiabg2da9iaadcfadaqadaqaaiaadQfacqGH+aGpcaaIXaGaaiOlai aaikdacaaI3aaacaGLOaGaayzkaaGaeyisISRaaGymaiabgkHiTiaa icdacaGGUaGaaGioaiaaiMdacaaI4aGaaGimaiabg2da9iaaicdaca GGUaGaaGymaiaaicdacaaIYaGaaGimaiaac6caaaa@527D@

Part (b):

(i) Let W represent the weight of a randomly selected full carton of eggs, P the weight of the packaging, and Xi the weight of the ith egg, for i = … 1, 2, , 12.

Note that W = P + X1 + X2 +…+ X12.

Properties of expected values establish that E(W) = E(P) + E(X12). Because all 12 eggs have the same mean weight, this becomes E(W) = E(P) + 12 x E(Xi).

We were told that E(W) = 840 and E(P) = 20, so we can solve 840 = 20 + 12 x E(Xi) to find E ( X i ) = 840 − 20 12 ≈ 68.33 MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiVu0Je9sqqrpepC0xbbL8F4rqqrFfpeea0xe9Lq=Jc9 vqaqpepm0xbba9pwe9Q8fs0=yqaqpepae9pg0FirpepeKkFr0xfr=x fr=xb9adbaqaaeGaciGaaiaabeqaamaabaabaaGcbaGaamyramaabm aabaGaamiwamaaBaaaleaacaWGPbaabeaaaOGaayjkaiaawMcaaiab g2da9maalaaabaGaaGioaiaaisdacaaIWaGaeyOeI0IaaGOmaiaaic daaeaacaaIXaGaaGOmaaaacqGHijYUcaaI2aGaaGioaiaac6cacaaI ZaGaaG4maaaa@46D3@ grams.

(ii) Because of independence, properties of variance establish that Var(W) = Var(P) + Var(X1) + Var(X2) +…+ Var( X12).

Because all 12 eggs have the same variance of their weights, this becomes Var(W) = Var(P) + 12 x Var(Xi).

We were told that SD(W) = 7.9 and SD (P) = 1.7. Therefore, Var(W) = (7.9)2 = 62.41 and Var(P) = (1.7)2 = 2.89.

We can solve 62.41 = 2.89 + 12 x Var(Xi) = 62.41 − 2.89 12 MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiVu0Je9sqqrpepC0xbbL8F4rqqrFfpeea0xe9Lq=Jc9 vqaqpepm0xbba9pwe9Q8fs0=yqaqpepae9pg0FirpepeKkFr0xfr=x fr=xb9adbaqaaeGaciGaaiaabeqaamaabaabaaGcbaWaaSaaaeaaca aI2aGaaGOmaiaac6cacaaI0aGaaGymaiabgkHiTiaaikdacaGGUaGa aGioaiaaiMdaaeaacaaIXaGaaGOmaaaaaaa@3F04@ = 4.96. Thus, SD(Xi) = ( 4.96 ) ≈ 2.23 MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiVu0Je9sqqrpepC0xbbL8F4rqqrFfpeea0xe9Lq=Jc9 vqaqpepm0xbba9pwe9Q8fs0=yqaqpepae9pg0FirpepeKkFr0xfr=x fr=xb9adbaqaaeGaciGaaiaabeqaamaabaabaaGcbaWaaOaaaeaada qadaqaaiaaisdacaGGUaGaaGyoaiaaiAdaaiaawIcacaGLPaaaaSqa baGccqGHijYUcaaIYaGaaiOlaiaaikdacaaIZaaaaa@3F2F@ grams.

Scoring

Parts (a), (b-i), and (b-ii) were scored as essentially correct (E), partially correct (P), or incorrect (I). (Minor arithmetic errors in any part were not penalized).

Part (a) is scored as follows:

Essentially correct (E) if the response correctly includes the following three components:

  • Indicates use of a normal distribution and clearly identifies the correct parameter values (using a z-score is sufficient);

  • Uses the correct boundary value;

  • Reports the correct normal probability consistent with components 1 and 2.

Partially correct (P) if the response correctly includes two of the three components listed above.

Incorrect (I) if the response does not satisfy the criteria for an E or a P.

Notes:

  • An error in statistical notation in the response lowers the score one level (that is, from E to P or from P to I).

  • Responses that calculate a probability for a sample mean with n not equal to 1 should be scored an I. For example, using z = x − μ σ / n MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiVu0Je9sqqrpepC0xbbL8F4rqqrFfpeea0xe9Lq=Jc9 vqaqpepm0xbba9pwe9Q8fs0=yqaqpepae9pg0FirpepeKkFr0xfr=x fr=xb9adbaqaaeGaciGaaiaabeqaamaabaabaaGcbaGaamOEaiabg2 da9maalaaabaGaamiEaiabgkHiTiabeY7aTbqaaiabeo8aZjaac+ca daGcaaqaaiaad6gaaSqabaaaaaaa@3F2F@ , even if the parameters were correctly identified.

  • In component 1, a sketch of a normal curve with the mean labeled is sufficient for indicating use of a normal distribution and identifying the mean.

  • The following were examples of clearly identified parameters for component 1:

    • Writes “μ = 840,σ = 7.9 .”

    • Explicitly labels the mean and standard deviation in a normalcdf calculator statement.

    • Sketches a normal curve, labels 840 as the mean, and labels two additional consecutive values separated by 7.9.

  • For component 3, acceptable correct values were all in the interval from 0.1020 to 0.1038.

Part (b-i) is scored as follows:

Essentially correct (E) if the response correctly uses properties of expected values to set up the correct equation to be solved AND correctly solves the equation for the desired expected value
OR
If the response follows a correct numerical procedure to find the correct expected value for one egg.

Partially correct (P) if the response indicates a correct procedure but makes an error in applying properties of expected values.
OR
If the response provides poor communication of the procedure.

Incorrect (I) if the response does not satisfy the criteria for an E or P.

Part (b-ii) is scored as follows:

Essentially correct (E) if the response combines variances and correctly includes the following three components:

  • Subtracts variances

  • Correctly uses the “12” in the calculations

  • Reports the correct standard deviation, consistent with components (1) and (2)

Partially correct (P) if the response combines variances and correctly includes two of the three components listed above.

Incorrect (I) if the response does not satisfy the criteria for an E or P.

Intent of Question

The primary goals of this question were to assess a student’s ability to (1) calculate a probability from a normal distribution and (2) apply properties of means and variances of functions of random variables.

Solution

Part (a):

Let W denote the weight of a randomly selected full carton of eggs. W has a normal distribution with mean 840 grams and standard deviation 7.9 grams.

The z-score for a weight of 850 grams is z= 850−840 7.9 ≈1.27. The standard normal probability table reveals that

P( W>850 )=P( Z>1.27 )≈1−0.8980=0.1020. Part (b):

(i) Let W represent the weight of a randomly selected full carton of eggs, P the weight of the packaging, and Xi the weight of the ith egg, for i = … 1, 2, , 12.

Note that W = P + X1 + X2 +…+ X12.

Properties of expected values establish that E(W) = E(P) + E(X12). Because all 12 eggs have the same mean weight, this becomes E(W) = E(P) + 12 x E(Xi).

We were told that E(W) = 840 and E(P) = 20, so we can solve 840 = 20 + 12 x E(Xi) to find E( X i )= 840−20 12 ≈68.33 MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiVu0Je9sqqrpepC0xbbL8F4rqqrFfpeea0xe9Lq=Jc9 vqaqpepm0xbba9pwe9Q8fs0=yqaqpepae9pg0FirpepeKkFr0xfr=x fr=xb9adbaqaaeGaciGaaiaabeqaamaabaabaaGcbaGaamyramaabm aabaGaamiwamaaBaaaleaacaWGPbaabeaaaOGaayjkaiaawMcaaiab g2da9maalaaabaGaaGioaiaaisdacaaIWaGaeyOeI0IaaGOmaiaaic daaeaacaaIXaGaaGOmaaaacqGHijYUcaaI2aGaaGioaiaac6cacaaI ZaGaaG4maaaa@46D3@ grams.

(ii) Because of independence, properties of variance establish that Var(W) = Var(P) + Var(X1) + Var(X2) +…+ Var( X12).

Because all 12 eggs have the same variance of their weights, this becomes Var(W) = Var(P) + 12 x Var(Xi).

We were told that SD(W) = 7.9 and SD (P) = 1.7. Therefore, Var(W) = (7.9)2 = 62.41 and Var(P) = (1.7)2 = 2.89.

We can solve 62.41 = 2.89 + 12 x Var(Xi) = 62.41−2.89 12 MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiVu0Je9sqqrpepC0xbbL8F4rqqrFfpeea0xe9Lq=Jc9 vqaqpepm0xbba9pwe9Q8fs0=yqaqpepae9pg0FirpepeKkFr0xfr=x fr=xb9adbaqaaeGaciGaaiaabeqaamaabaabaaGcbaWaaSaaaeaaca aI2aGaaGOmaiaac6cacaaI0aGaaGymaiabgkHiTiaaikdacaGGUaGa aGioaiaaiMdaaeaacaaIXaGaaGOmaaaaaaa@3F04@ = 4.96. Intent of Question

The primary goals of this question were to assess a student’s ability to (1) calculate a probability from a normal distribution and (2) apply properties of means and variances of functions of random variables.

Solution

Part (a):

Let W denote the weight of a randomly selected full carton of eggs. W has a normal distribution with mean 840 grams and standard deviation 7.9 grams.

The z-score for a weight of 850 grams is z= 850−840 7.9 ≈1.27. Properties of expected values establish that E(W) = E(P) + E(X12). Because all 12 eggs have the same mean weight, this becomes E(W) = E(P) + 12 x E(Xi).

Complete Response

Intent of Question

The primary goals of this question were to assess a student’s ability to (1) calculate a probability from a normal distribution and (2) apply properties of means and variances of functions of random variables.

Solution

Part (a):

Let W denote the weight of a randomly selected full carton of eggs. W has a normal distribution with mean 840 grams and standard deviation 7.9 grams.

The z-score for a weight of 850 grams is z= 850−840 7.9 ≈1.27. The standard normal probability table reveals that

P( W>850 )=P( Z>1.27 )≈1−0.8980=0.1020. Part (b):

(i) Let W represent the weight of a randomly selected full carton of eggs, P the weight of the packaging, and Xi the weight of the ith egg, for i = … 1, 2, , 12.

Note that W = P + X1 + X2 +…+ X12.

Properties of expected values establish that E(W) = E(P) + E(X12). Because all 12 eggs have the same mean weight, this becomes E(W) = E(P) + 12 x E(Xi).

We were told that E(W) = 840 and E(P) = 20, so we can solve 840 = 20 + 12 x E(Xi) to find E( X i )= 840−20 12 ≈68.33 MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiVu0Je9sqqrpepC0xbbL8F4rqqrFfpeea0xe9Lq=Jc9 vqaqpepm0xbba9pwe9Q8fs0=yqaqpepae9pg0FirpepeKkFr0xfr=x fr=xb9adbaqaaeGaciGaaiaabeqaamaabaabaaGcbaGaamyramaabm aabaGaamiwamaaBaaaleaacaWGPbaabeaaaOGaayjkaiaawMcaaiab g2da9maalaaabaGaaGioaiaaisdacaaIWaGaeyOeI0IaaGOmaiaaic daaeaacaaIXaGaaGOmaaaacqGHijYUcaaI2aGaaGioaiaac6cacaaI ZaGaaG4maaaa@46D3@ grams.

(ii) Because of independence, properties of variance establish that Var(W) = Var(P) + Var(X1) + Var(X2) +…+ Var( X12).

Because all 12 eggs have the same variance of their weights, this becomes Var(W) = Var(P) + 12 x Var(Xi).

We were told that SD(W) = 7.9 and SD (P) = 1.7. Therefore, Var(W) = (7.9)2 = 62.41 and Var(P) = (1.7)2 = 2.89.

We can solve 62.41 = 2.89 + 12 x Var(Xi) = 62.41−2.89 12 MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiVu0Je9sqqrpepC0xbbL8F4rqqrFfpeea0xe9Lq=Jc9 vqaqpepm0xbba9pwe9Q8fs0=yqaqpepae9pg0FirpepeKkFr0xfr=x fr=xb9adbaqaaeGaciGaaiaabeqaamaabaabaaGcbaWaaSaaaeaaca aI2aGaaGOmaiaac6cacaaI0aGaaGymaiabgkHiTiaaikdacaGGUaGa aGioaiaaiMdaaeaacaaIXaGaaGOmaaaaaaa@3F04@ = 4.96. Scoring

Parts (a), (b-i), and (b-ii) were scored as essentially correct (E), partially correct (P), or incorrect (I). (Minor arithmetic errors in any part were not penalized).

Part (a) is scored as follows:

Essentially correct (E) if the response correctly includes the following three components:

  • Indicates use of a normal distribution and clearly identifies the correct parameter values (using a z-score is sufficient);

  • Uses the correct boundary value;

  • Reports the correct normal probability consistent with components 1 and 2.

    • Partially correct (P) if the response correctly includes two of the three components listed above.

    Incorrect (I) if the response does not satisfy the criteria for an E or a P.
